text: Family Member: Ohh. Okay. Doctor: Don’t quote me. Patient: So I only have to come down once every three weeks? Yeah. Family Member: So what's the difference between the trial infusion timetable and the infusion of just getting the infusions. Doctor: None. It's still once every three weeks. Family Member: Yeah, there's no difference? Doctor: There's no difference. So it's just if you get on the study arm and you get the pill chemo version, then you might have a slightly different schedule. And I should know all that except I rely heavily on my research nurse to make sure that's right. Because they change the schedule sometimes so often, and I'm just gonna so ask S____ to help me. Family Member: Yeah guess the question I have is, what if for some reason the roads are really bad, the weather’s really bad? Are you flexible? Doctor: Oh, we would just reschedule. Oh, yes. We would never put you at risk for safety. If let's say you're just sick with something, it's not cancer related. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You don't come down. You got to do this hard thing. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes we have to be a little bit off cycle because, again, the weather for us is usually the big thing.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In about thirty to forty percent of patients it causes remissions. In other words it causes cancer either to shrink um partially or completely in addition to the PSA level to drop either partially or completely. Patient: I don’t understand how. Could you give me the basic outline as to how that is happening? Let’s say you have the person who is overweight; you give him more food. That doesn’t – Doctor: Yeah, as I said, as you pointed out, it seems like a paradox and it seems counterintuitive. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: And the reason is it has to do with the fact that um when the prostate cancer cell, the cancer cell has been in an environment where the testosterone has been deprived for so long, and then all of a sudden you give that cell back a super-high dose of testosterone, it shocks the system and it causes that cell to die. And the exact reason for that we’ve begun to tease it out and understand it better. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It turns out that the genetic material of the cancer cell, which is called the DNA. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in order for that cancer cell to be able to replicate itself, to cause you know two cells from one and then four cells, eight cells, it needs to be able to replicate its DNA and then replicate itself after that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it turns out when you give high doses of testosterone in the setting where that cell has previously been in a low testosterone environment - Patient: Okay.

That doesn’t – Doctor: Yeah, as I said, as you pointed out, it seems like a paradox and it seems counterintuitive. Patient: Right, right. And the exact reason for that we’ve begun to tease it out and understand it better. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It turns out that the genetic material of the cancer cell, which is called the DNA. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in order for that cancer cell to be able to replicate itself, to cause you know two cells from one and then four cells, eight cells, it needs to be able to replicate its DNA and then replicate itself after that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it turns out when you give high doses of testosterone in the setting where that cell has previously been in a low testosterone environment - Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get -- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: a second line hormone versus a second line hormone plus this new PARP drug versus this PARP drug. So, Patient: But, that will be a decision we will make together. Doctor: Yeah, and that’s a coin flip between all those three. Um. That’s kind of a random trial. So, we can talk about that. Um. The immune therapy story is an earlier - it’s still in it’s earlier phases, but people are starting to think, if you have these mutations, you’re making abnormal things on the - in the cell, and that might – and that’s what kind of gets the immune system excited, something that looks weird. And, maybe you would respond better – ‘cuz right now when we give these new immune drugs, they work really well for some cancers Kidney cancer, melanoma, lung cancer. They don’t work very well for prostate cancer in just the general population. So, we’re trying to --- we think they’re good drugs, but we’re trying to figure out what’s the best way to use those. Patient: They might be usable with somebody with the genetic mutation. Doctor: Right. That’s what they’re – we have some kind of preliminary evidence, that’s true. No one’s done a huge study yet to, to prove that. What we were – I told you about this study we’re trying to do which is, we had two men who got one of our testosterone studies, responded, stayed on the drug for about a year, came off the drug, got some other things, and then got an immune therapy trial, with the expectation that the, uh, the immune therapy doesn’t work really well. But, both of those guys had unbelievable response; a ninety-nine percent drop in their PSA, disease disappeared. So, we’re not exactly sure, but what they both had in common was that they got testosterone. So, our, our, one of our trials is looking at that combination. Does the testosterone change the cell surface or whatever? So, we can talk about that, too, but

text: Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So that's why it says maybe, but they don't- notably, they don't see any anywhere else, okay. So then today you had your bone scan and the bone scans in shows no evidence of metastatic disease. Okay so these are your two summaries. Family Member: Mm. Doctor: So this is CT scan and this is bone scan. Okay. So those are you for your information. So with, with that you really fit into the bucket of what we consider biochemical recurrence. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Okay, which is good. Now the question becomes what do we do with you cuz you're in this bucket, biochemical recurrence. So you have a PSA that's rising the cancer somewhere, it seems to be growing, albeit maybe not that fast and before it gets to somewhere to metastatic what do we, what do we do? Okay, so the options for treatment at this point, are 1- observation- and observation what that entails is just monitoring your PSA and periodically doing CAT scans and bone scans and waiting to see if when you develop metastatic disease. Patient: Mm. Doctor: Alright, and then starting treatment when you just when you develop metastatic disease. Option two is what we call intermittent hormone therapy. So, what this approach means is that you would get hormone therapy, which is the primary treatment for prostate cancer. If you were here in this metastatic bucket, you can get started with hormone therapy. But you would get started on hormone therapy for six months and then we stop and then and that'll bring down your PSA and then we wait until some threshold PSA, your PSA is about 31 now, so we could wait until it gets to 31 again. And sometimes we wait until it’s 10 sometimes 50, but you know, we would, we would only give you the hormone therapy intermittently, so not continuously so you get it for six months, two shots, shot us for three months, lasts for three months. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So you get it for two shots and then you stop. What this medicine does is it makes your testosterone levels go to zero. So it works on your testicles which produce the testosterone and it makes them stop producing testosterone. So people have like menopause type symptoms. Mm? Family Member: So you’re going to use Lupron? Doctor: Yes, exactly. Family Member: Mhm.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
